title: A block in a circular motion

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A small block of mass slides on a horizontal surface where friction between the block and the surface is negligible as it travels around the inside wall of a hoop of radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The coefficient of friction between the block and the wall is <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The block is given an initial speed <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> tangent to the hoop and allowed to travel along the inside edge. (a) The block is allowed to travel around the hoop for a time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. At that moment the speed of the block is <math alttext="v sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The experiment is repeated but the initial speed of the block in the second trial is greater than <math alttext="v sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Will the speed of the block after a time <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="v sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(b) Students derive the following equation for the speed of the block as a function of time: <math alttext="1 over v of , t equals the fraction with numerator mu sub k , t , and denominator r, end fraction, plus , 1 over v sub 0 ." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. Whether or not this equation is correct, does it match your claim in part (a)? Justify your answer.
(c) Briefly describe how students could use the equation from part (b) to derive an equation for the tangential acceleration of the block as a function of time.
(d) Without deriving equations, describe what will happen to the angular momentum of the block with respect to the center of the hoop as a function of time. Justify your answer.
(e) Students created the above graphs of the speed of the block as a function of time. Which of the labeled graphs correctly models the speed of the block as a function of time? Justify your answer.
(f) Describe briefly the relationship between the magnitude of the centripetal force on the block and the magnitude of the normal force applied by the hoop on the block. Justify your answer.
